title: Jordan Peele's fake news PSA with Barack Obama
brief_description: Jordan Peele turned his humour and filmmaking skills to creating a deepfake video of Barack Obama to draw attention to the dangers of the technology.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

title_for_label: Jordan Peele’s fake news PSA with Barack Obama
description: In a sobering example of the potential for ‘deepfake’ technology to create alternate realities beyond the cinematic sphere, in 2018, BuzzFeed and director Jordan Peele (Get Out, Us) voiced a cautionary PSA in which former U.S. president Barack Obama appears to offer contentious opinions on the history of the Black Panthers and President Trump. Peele’s production company created the clip using a combination of old and new technology: Adobe After Effects and the AI face-swapping tool, FakeApp. Peele’s intention was to draw attention to the capacity for AI to generate photorealistic fake videos that could be mis-used to spread disinformation. The clip ends by urging viewers to critically assess what they see on the internet and to ‘rely on trusted news sources’ to avert the potential dystopia that awaits us in a post-truth era of fake news.
